results.title: Bonnie and clyde [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Warren Beatty and Arthur Penn
results.brief_description: Alternating between comedy and tragedy, this violent and kinetic re-telling of the story of Bonnie and Clyde is justifiably one of the most celebrated American films of the sixties. Set in the early thirties of the Depression, a car thief and his girl-friend commit a series of robberies which earn them a reputation as America’s most feared criminals. Featuring superb production values and brilliant editing, Arthur Penn’s film is an ironic exploration of the romantic roots of the counter-culture in the myths and memories of the Depression, and within Hollywood’s depictions of the “outlaw”. The film’s controversial use of violence is simultaneously brutal and liberating. Cast includes Warren Beatty, Faye Dunaway and Gene Hackman.

results.title: Bonjour Toronto!
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Marcel Martin and Clement Perron
results.brief_description: A young Montrealer explores Toronto for the first time. Despite some ready-made notions, the visitor is eager to look and learn, and before long is caught by the excitement of the Queen City. Although some of his prior convictions are confirmed, he finds, somewhat to his surprise, that the city has much to offer, including a French bookstore. Features songs “The Times I’ve Had” and “The Crow On The Cradle” sung by American folk singer Carloyn Hester. At the end of the film, footage of Carolyn Hester performing the song “This Life I’m Living in” is also featured; as the narrator explains “in the semi-religious darkness…” of a coffee house at night.

results.title: Bonjour Paris = Hello Paris
results.creator_credit: Jean Image, Mose Sachs and Peter Sachs
results.brief_description:
Two pigeons in love are flying above Paris. They visit their friend the Eiffel Tower who is suffering from stress. Today is a celebration day in Paris and the tower would like to participate, but its large size and clumsiness only serves to create mayhem. The tower decides to go and spend some time in the country, leaving crowds of angry Parisians looking for the soul of their City. Hearing of government plans to build a new Eiffel Tower and glad to be missed so dearly, the original tower decides to reappear.

Credits: Directors, Jean Image, Mose and Peter Sachs ; writers, Eraine, Claude Santelli, Paul Colline ; photography, Kostia Tchikine ; music, Jean Yatove.
Cast: Francois Perier [voice only].

results.title: Bonjour Balwyn
results.creator_credit: Experimental Film Fund, Australia Council for the Arts and Nigel Buesst
results.brief_description: A feature film about a young man’s futile attempt to publish a trendy magazine in Carlton. When his efforts begin to fail, he must turn to petty crime to help make ends meet. Stars John Duigan and Peter Cummins.

results.title: Bones and muscles (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Young Japanese athletes create awareness of how the human skeletal and muscular systems work together to allow movement of the body. A frog specimen shows how the muscles in the upper arm contract and relax so that arm bones can be moved. Discusses the functions of tendons, cartilage, and ligaments and examines various bones, joints, and vertebrae.

results.title: Bonds and relationships. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Country education Project-Ministry of Education, Daryl Wayland and David Zweck
results.brief_description: A panel led by Peter Couchman, (Don Edgar, Institute of Family Affairs Jenni Strauss and Dr. Christopher Worth, Monash University and Colin Goodwin of Philip Institute) discuss the HSC literature theme which concentrates on the family and the connections which operate within families. In Part 1 the texts “Father and son” by Edmund Gosse and “Long day’s journey into night” by Eugene O’Neill are considered. Covers such topics as the changing mix of families, the stress of being oneself in a family relationship and yet still being part of a family, and the kinds of support available for people facing problems. Part 2 looks at more contemporary issues that affect family relationships. The texts “The Millstone” by Margaret Drabble and “A Very easy death” by Simone de Beauvoir are considered.

results.title: Bonds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
This film describes why different types of bonds are used and proceeds to demonstrate various bonds. It explains that “bonding” means to arrange bricks to a definite pattern according to function. A wall in “Flemish” bond is shown and its construction demonstrated in a one brick and a one and a half brick wall. “English” bond is then dealt with followed by “Dutch” bond. English and Flemish garden wall bonds bring the film to a close.

results.title: Bonanza: The Ape. The Savage
results.creator_credit: National Broadcasting Company and David Dortort
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Bonanza”.
The Ape (dir. James P. Yarbrough): Hoss befriends Arnie Gurne - a lumbering, disabled, man who knows how to fight. Hoss, respectful of his physical prowess, puts Arnie to work on the farm. His best intentions backfire however when Hoss is accused of harbouring a criminal after Arnie turns on the object of his affection, saloon girl Sharie, and kills her. A posse is set out to capture the misunderstood Gurne. “The Savage” (dir. James Neilson): Shoshone Indians kill two fur trappers after they enter a sacred burial ground. Of this tribe, two of them cross over the forbidden stone to find the spirit of White Buffalo Woman to save their ailing tribe. When one of them makes contact with her, they discover she is a flesh and blood white woman, not a spirit, and vow to kidnap her and return to the village exposing her mortality. Adam is injured by Indians protecting the woman and finds himself nursed by White Buffalo Woman with whom he falls in love. Cast includes: Dan Blocker, Michael Landon, Lorne Greene, Pernell Roberts.
